search_context:
### Injury Report
**Golden State Warriors:**
- Stephen Curry (PG): OUT (knee soreness)[1][2][3]
- Seth Curry (PG/SG): OUT (sciatic-nerve issue/thigh/right toe soreness)[1][2][3]
- L.J. Cryer (PG): OUT/QUESTIONABLE (hamstring strain)[1][2][3]
- Jimmy Butler III (SF/PF): OUT (torn right ACL, season-ending)[1][2][3]
- Kristaps Porzingis (C/PF): OUT (Achilles-related issue)[1][2][3]
- Brandin Podziemski (PG/SG): PROBABLE/DAY-TO-DAY (illness)[1][2][3]

**Los Angeles Lakers:**
- Luka Doncic (PG/SF): OUT (hamstring strain, out through at least February 9)[1][2][3][5]
- Adou Thiero (SF/SG): OUT (right knee/MCL sprain)[1][2]
- Luke Kennard (SG): QUESTIONABLE/PROBABLE (pending trade/illness)[1][2]
- Jaxson Hayes (C): QUESTIONABLE (suspension for pushing mascot)[2]
- Deandre Ayton (C): Available/day-to-day (knee pain, not severe; played in prior game vs. Warriors)[4][6]

### Betting Lines
Lakers favored by **2.5 points**. Projected over/under total between **222.5 and 223.5**[1].

### Line Movement
No relevant information on opening lines or notable moves.

### Recent News
Lakers defeated Warriors 105-99 on February 7, 2026, without Curry or Doncic; Reaves had 7 first-half assists amid defensive attention[4][5]. Deandre Ayton scratched late for February 7 game due to knee pain but deemed day-to-day and not severe; Lakers coach JJ Redick not concerned[4]. Official NBA injury report on February 8 lists Ayton available; Lakers not yet submitted full report for OKC@LAL[6]. Play-by-in-progress notes from February 8 game show active players including Moody, Green, Hayes, Kennard, Podziemski, LaRavia[7].

### Additional Context
### Injury Statuses

**Golden State Warriors:**
- Stephen Curry (PG): OUT (knee soreness; no confirmed return date)[1][2][3].
- Seth Curry (PG/SG): OUT (left sciatic-nerve issue/thigh/right toe soreness)[1][2][3].
- Jimmy Butler III (SF/PF): OUT for season (torn right ACL, injured 1/20/26)[1][2][3].
- Kristaps Porzingis (C/PF): OUT (Achilles-related issue)[1][2][3].
- L.J. Cryer (PG): OUT (hamstring strain, updated 2/6/26) or QUESTIONABLE (hamstring, updated 2/6/26)[1][2].
- Brandin Podziemski (PG/SG): **PROBABLE** (illness; projected to play and expected in starting lineup at PG, updated 12:21p 2/7/26)[1][2][3].
These absences force reliance on Draymond Green (PF, facilitating), Moses Moody (SG), Al Horford (C), and Gui Santos (SF) in expected lineup, emphasizing half-court offense without Curry's scoring/playmaking (19.9 PPG, 4.6 APG, 3.3 3PM)[1][6].

**Los Angeles Lakers:**
- Luka Doncic (PG/SF): OUT (hamstring strain; out through at least 2/9/26, updated 2/6/26)[1][2][5].
- Adou Thiero (SF/SG): OUT (right knee/MCL sprain, no timetable; out since 2/2/26)[1][2].
- Luke Kennard (SG): QUESTIONABLE/PROBABLE (pending trade/illness, updated 12:20p 2/7/26)[1][2].
- Jaxson Hayes (C): QUESTIONABLE (one-game suspension for pushing mascot, updated 2/5/26)[2].
- Deandre Ayton (C): Available (per 2/8/26 10AM official report)[4].
Lakers lean on LeBron James (point-forward, 21.7 PPG, 6.4 APG), Austin Reaves (PG), Marcus Smart (SG, 9.2 PPG), Rui Hachimura (PF), and Jake LaRavia (SF, 10.6 PPG) in expected lineup; Ayton anchors paint defense/rebounding (10.9 PPG, 7.5 RPG)[1][4][6].

Warriors' four simultaneous star-level outs (Curry, Seth Curry, Butler, Porzingis) exceed Lakers' absences in severity/scope, thinning guard depth and frontcourt[1][3].

### Betting Line and Adjustments

Lakers are **2.5-point home favorites**; total at **222.5-223.5** (or 221.5 per one source)[1][2].  
- Warriors lead H2H 1-0 (119-109 Opening Night 2025); 5-4 over last three seasons[1].  
- Team stats (entering 2/7/26): Warriors 28-24 (~116.2 PPG, 113.6 PAPG, 46.1% FG); Lakers 31-19 (~116.3 PPG, 116.1 PAPG, 49.8% FG)[1].  
No sources detail sharp money movements or line adjustments; Lakers' recent 105-99 win over Warriors (2/7/26, both missing Curry/Doncic) occurred with sluggish pace/low output, highlighting injury impacts on scoring[5].

### Warriors' Backup Ball-Handling and Offensive Efficiency

Podziemski (**PROBABLE**) is primary backup handler (10.9 PPG, 3.9 APG, 4.6 RPG, 1.3 3PM); expected to start at PG with Green facilitating[1][6].  
Other options: De'Anthony Melton (11.8 PPG, 2 APG), Moody; no data on sustained efficiency without Curry (team ~116.2 PPG relies on his 19.9 PPG/3.3 3PM)[1][6].  
Absences drop pace to structured half-court sets, risking lower totals vs. 222.5-223.5 (Lakers shoot 49.8% FG efficiently inside)[1]. Official 2/8/26 10AM report unsubmitted for Warriors/Lakers[4].
